review: One day I'm gonna tell my grandkids that I was alive when this masterpiece was published and they weren't. This book captures the essence of its era so perfectly. The prose is absolutely stunning, and the characters feel so real. It's hard to believe this was written so long ago - it feels timeless.

Fitzgerald's masterpiece remains as relevant today as it was a century ago. The exploration of the American Dream and its disillusionment is beautifully crafted. Gatsby's character is both tragic and compelling.
This is the quintessential American novel. Every sentence is perfectly crafted, every scene meticulously placed. The symbolism and themes are layered beautifully throughout. A true work of art.

The Great Gatsby is a stunning portrayal of the Jazz Age. The decadence, the longing, the tragedy - it's all there. Nick Carraway's narration provides the perfect lens through which to view this world.
While I found some parts slow, the overall impact of this novel is undeniable. The green light, the eyes of Dr. T.J. Eckleburg - these symbols stay with you long after reading.
Fitzgerald's prose is simply magical. The way he describes the parties, the characters, the setting - it's like poetry. This book deserves every bit of praise it receives.
A brilliant examination of wealth, love, and the pursuit of happiness. Gatsby's story is both inspiring and heartbreaking. The ending still gives me chills.

This is one of the most astonishing and original works to come out of this period. You don't have to even like the style to know that it is at this point in literary history that their creative genius was overflowing beyond what seemed "imaginable."

This book broke boundaries and continues to resonate with readers today. The social commentary is sharp, the narrative is compelling, and the impact is undeniable. A must-read for anyone interested in classic literature.
